[[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], Canada |website = {{URL|www.dnd.ca}} }} The '''Department of National Defence''' ({{lang-fr|Ministère de la Défense nationale}}), commonly abbreviated as '''DND''', is a [[Government of Canada|Canadian government]] [[Cabinet of Canada|department]] responsible for defending Canada's interests and values at home and abroad.{{cite web |url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/pri/first-premier/roles-eng.asp | title=Canada First Defence Strategy -Roles | publisher=Department of National Defence | date=January 13, 2012 | accessdate=March 8, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.civ.forces.gc.ca/working-travailler/index-eng.asp | title=DND Jobs Home | publisher=Department of National Defence | date=August 5, 2011 | accessdate=March 8, 2012}} National Defence is the largest department of the Government of Canada in terms of budget as well as staff. It also is the department with the largest number of buildings (6,806 in 2015).{{cite web|title=Organizations by number of buildings|url=http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/dfrp-rbif/reports-rapports/top-haut/buildings-immeubles-eng.aspx|website=Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat|publisher=Government of Canada|accessdate=8 September 2015}} The Department is headed by the Deputy Minister of National Defence, who is the Department’s senior civil servant, and reports directly to the [[Minister of National Defence (Canada)|Minister of National Defence]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/about/faq.page#q7 | title=About DND -What is the relationship between DND and the Canadian Forces? | publisher=Department of National Defence |date=February 1, 2012|accessdate=March 8, 2012}} The Department of National Defence exists to aid the minister in carrying out his responsibilities within the Defence Portfolio, and provides a civilian support system for the [[Canadian Forces|Canadian Armed Forces]].{{cite web | url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/jobs-civilian/civilian-career-jobs-faq.page? | title=Civilian Career and Jobs FAQ | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | date=22 July 2013 | accessdate=27 October 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://www.civ.forces.gc.ca/support-appui/csa-aft-eng.asp |title=Civilians Supporting the Army | publisher=Department of National Defence | date=August 5, 2011 |accessdate=March 8, 2012}} Under the [[National Defence Act]], the Canadian Armed Forces is a completely separate and distinct organization from, and is not part of, the Department of National Defence.{{cite web | url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/about/faq.page? | title=Defence Home - Frequently Asked Questions | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | date=27 July 2013 | accessdate=27 October 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/about/canadian-armed-forces.page | title=About the Canadian Armed Forces | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | date=27 July 2013 | accessdate=3 April 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/about-us.page | title=About the Department of National Defence and the Canadian Armed Forces - National Defence Act | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | date=23 May 2013 | accessdate=3 April 2015}} The Department of National Defence is currently headed by Deputy Minister John Forster.{{cite web | url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/about-org-structure/deputy-minister-national-defence.page? | title=Deputy Minister of National Defence - Biography | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | date=12 September 2013 | accessdate=27 October 2013}} ==History== [[File:Cdndepartmentdefense.jpg|thumb|left|230px|[[NDHQ|National Defence Headquarters]] in [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]]] The Department of National Defence was established by the [[National Defence Act]], which merged the [[Department of Militia and Defence (Canada)|Department of Militia and Defence]] (which was created in 1906 when the British Army withdrew its forces stationed in Canada), the [[Department of Naval Services]] (the department responsible for the administration of the [[Royal Canadian Navy]]), and the [[Air Board (Canada)|Air Board]] (which oversaw aviation in Canada). The National Defence Act was passed by the [[Parliament of Canada]] on June 28, 1922.{{cite book|last=Gough|first=Barry|title=Historical Dictionary of Canada|year=2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=0-8108-5496-1|authorlink=Barry M. Gough|page=xxxvii}} ==Organization== [[Image:Defence_Team_Organisational_Structure_2014.jpg|right|400px]] Both the Canadian Armed Forces (military) and the Department of National Defence (civilian civil servants) are, although two separate organizations, known collectively as the '''Defence Team''' as both institutions work closely together in the defence of Canada. The Minister of National Defence, as the member of cabinet responsible to Parliament for National Defence, heads the Defence Team. The Department of National Defence is headed by the Deputy Minister of National Defence. Under the Deputy Minister are a variety of associate deputy and assistant deputy ministers who are responsible for various aspects of the department (human resources, policy, etc.). The Deputy Minister is appointed by the Governor General on behalf of the Queen of Canada ([[Queen-in-Council]]) on the [[advice (constitutional)|advice]] of the Prime Minister.{{cite web | url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/about-notresujet/index-eng.asp | title=The Deputy Minister of National Defence | publisher=Department of National Defence | date=February 1, 2012 | accessdate=March 8, 2012}}{{cite web | url=http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/N-5/page-2.html#h-6 | title=National Defence Act | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | year=2012 | accessdate=September 2, 2012 | pages=R.S., c. N-4, s. 7.}} The Canadian Armed Forces, as a separate and distinct organization, is headed by the Chief of the Defence Staff, and reporting to him are the Royal Canadian Navy, Canadian Army, Royal Canadian Air Force, and a variety of other commands. There are also a variety of offices and support organizations which report to both the Chief of Defence Staff and the Deputy Minister. The [[Monarchy in Canada|Canadian Sovereign]], represented by the [[Governor General of Canada|Governor General]], is responsible for appointing the Minister, Deputy Minister, and Chief of Defence Staff on the recommendation of the [[Queen's Privy Council of Canada]]. Although not part of the Defence Team organizational structure, the legal military chain-of-command within the Canadian Forces originates from the Queen of Canada as [[Commander-in-Chief of Canada|Commander-in-Chief]] (represented by the Governor General), through the Chief of the Defence Staff to all military officers by virtue of their holding of the Queen’s Commission, and thus through them to all members of the Canadian Armed Forces.{{cite web | url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/about-org-structure/chief-of-defence-staff.page | title=Role of the Chief of Defence Staff | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | date=17 April 2014 | accessdate=3 April 2015}} ==The Defence Portfolio== {{Main|Minister of National Defence (Canada)}} The Minister of National Defence is responsible for the entire Defence Portfolio comprising several organizations, including the Canadian Forces, the [[Communications Security Establishment]], [[Defence Research and Development Canada]], and the Department of National Defence, amongst others. The Department is not responsible for all of these organizations itself, but rather exists to support the minister in carrying out all of his duties within the Defence Portfolio. The Canadian Forces are a distinct and separate entity from the Department of National Defence. ==See also== {{Portal|Canadian Armed Forces|Canadian politics}} {{Commons category|Canadian Armed Forces}} {{Commons category|Department of National Defence (Canada)}} {{Commons category|Department of National Defence Headquarters}} * [[Minister of National Defence (Canada)|Minister of National Defence]] * [[Canadian Forces]] ** [[Royal Canadian Navy]] ** [[Canadian Army]] ** [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] *[[Military history of Canada]] **[[History of the Canadian Army]] **[[History of the Royal Canadian Navy]] **[[History of the Royal Canadian Air Force]] * [[Armed Forces Council]] * [[Union of National Defence Employees]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{coord|45.423339|-75.68924|type:landmark_region:CA|display=title}} ==External links== * [http://www.forces.gc.ca Department of National Defence and Canadian Forces] *[http://utarms.library.utoronto.ca/ Archival papers held at University of Toronto Archives and Records Management Services] {{Government Departments of Canada}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Department Of National Defence (Canada)}} [[Category:Department of National Defence (Canada)| ]] [[Category:Canadian federal departments and agencies|National Defence]] [[Category:Military of Canada]] [[Category:Defence ministries|Canada]] [[Category:Ministries established in 1923]] [[Category:1923 establishments in Canada]]
